{{Other uses|Stewardship council (disambiguation){{!}}Stewardship council}} {{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=July 2016}} {{Primary sources|date=January 2017}} }}
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox company| name = Marine Stewardship Council | logo = [[File:MSC ecolabel.png|125px]] | type = [[Nonprofit organization]] | foundation = {{start date|1996}}; [[London]], [[United Kingdom]]<ref name="MSC history">{{cite web|url=http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/how_we_work/conservation/marine/sustainable_fishing/sustainable_seafood/ |title=MSC history |date= |accessdate=2015-12-29}}</ref> | location = Marine House, Snow Hill, London, {{postcode|EC|1}} | key_people = {{unbulleted list|Rupert Howes <small>(CEO)</small>|Werner Kiene <small>(Chair of the Board of Trustees)</small>|}} | industry = Sustainable seafood labelling | revenue = | net_income = | num_employees = {{Circa}} 140 | subsid = | homepage = {{url|http://www.msc.org}} | footnotes = <ref name="msc.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/business-support/key-facts-about-msc |title=MSC in numbers — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date=2013-03-21 |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> }} The '''Marine Stewardship Council''' ('''MSC''') is an independent [[non-profit organization]] which sets a standard for [[sustainable fishing]]. Fisheries that wish to demonstrate they are well-managed and sustainable compared to the science-based MSC standard are assessed by a team of experts who are independent of both the fishery and the MSC. [[Seafood products]] can display the blue MSC [[ecolabel]] only if that seafood can be traced back through the supply chain to a fishery that has been certified against the MSC standard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/about-us/standards/standards |title=MSC standards — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
The mission of the MSC is to use its ecolabel, for which the MSC receives [[Royalty payment|royalties]] for licensing it to products, and fishery certification program to contribute to the health of the world’s oceans by recognizing and rewarding sustainable fishing practices, influencing the choices people make when buying seafood, and working with partners to transform the seafood market to a sustainable basis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/about-us/vision-mission |title=Vision and mission — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> Another organisation, the [[Aquaculture Stewardship Council]], promotes and certifies sustainable [[aquaculture]].
==Contribution to changes in the oceans==
When buyers choose MSC-certified fish, well-managed fisheries are rewarded for sustainable practices. In turn, the growing market for certified [[sustainable seafood]] generates a powerful incentive for other fisheries to demonstrate they are fishing sustainably or to improve their performance so that they too can be eligible for MSC certification. In this way, the MSC program helps to harness market forces to incentivise positive environmental change.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/business-support/theory-of-change |title=Our theory of change — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
==Environmental benefits==
A study found that MSC-certified fisheries show improvements that deliver benefits to the marine environment. Benefits included: increased stocks; improved management of stocks; reduced bycatch; expansion of environmentally protected areas; and increased knowledge about ecosystem impacts amongst fishers.<ref>{{cite web|author=Erik Stokstad |url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/334/6057/746 |title=Science | From AAAS |publisher=M.sciencemag.org |date=2011-11-11 |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/business-support/environmental-improvements |title=Environmental impacts of the MSC program — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> A further study published in the scientific journal PLoS One found
==Key facts and figures==
The MSC was founded in 1996, inspired by the [[Grand Banks of Newfoundland|Grand Banks]] [[Collapse of the Atlantic northwest cod fishery|cod fishery collapse]]. In 1999 it became independent of its founding partners, the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] (WWF) and [[Unilever]].<ref name="MSC history"/> MSC has a staff of around 140 spread across the headquarters in London, regional offices in London, Seattle, Singapore and Sydney, and local offices in Edinburgh, Berlin, The Hague, Paris, Cape Town, Tokyo, Reykjavik, and the Baltic region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/about-us/offices-staff |title=Offices and staff — MSC |publisher=msc.org |date=2012-06-29 |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
The MSC program is open to all fisheries regardless of size, scale, location and intensity and runs a Developing World Program to ensure equal access to the program.
As of February 2016, there are over 20,000 [[seafood]] products available with the MSC ecolabel, sold in around 100 countries around the world. As of May 2016, there are over 280 fisheries that have been independently certified as meeting the MSC’s environmental standard for sustainable fishing and over 90 are currently undergoing assessment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/track-a-fishery/certified/certified-fisheries-on-the-map |title=Certified fisheries on the map — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2016-07-13}}</ref> Around 3,300 companies operating in 34,500 sites have met the MSC Chain of Custody standard for seafood traceability.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.msc.org/about-us/ocean-to-plate-traceability/ocean-to-plate-traceability |title=MSC Chain of Custody Standard for seafood traceability |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2016-07-13}}</ref> The MSC works in partnership with a number of organisations, businesses and funders around the world but is fully independent of all.<ref name="msc.org"/>
==Standard for sustainable fishing==
The MSC environmental standard for sustainable fishing was developed over two years through a [[Public consultation|consultative]] process involving more than 300 expert organizations and individuals around the world. It is consistent with the ‘Guidelines for the Eco-labelling of Fish and Fishery Products from Marine Wild Capture Fisheries’ adopted by the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/012/i1119t/i1119t00.htm |title=Guidelines for the Ecolabelling of Fish and Fishery Products from Marine Capture Fisheries. Revision 1. / Directives pour l'étiquetage écologique du poisson et des produits des pêches de capture marines. Révision 1. / Directrices para el ecoetiquetado de pescado y productos pesqueros de la pesca de captura marina. Revisión 1. / |publisher=Fao.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
===Principles of sustainability===
The MSC standard consists of three core principles that each fishery must demonstrate it meets:
* Principle 1: Sustainable fish stocks The fishing activity must be at a level which is sustainable for the targeted fish population. Any certified fishery must operate so that fishing can continue indefinitely and is not overexploiting the resources. * Principle 2: Minimising environmental impact Fishing operations should be managed to maintain the structure, productivity, function and diversity of the ecosystem on which the fishery depends. * Principle 3: Effective management The fishery must meet all local, national and international laws and must have a management system in place to respond to changing circumstances and maintain sustainability.
===How sustainability is measured===
Under the three principles are a total of 28 performance indicators that a fishery is scored against by an independent team of [[experts]]. The minimum passing score for each of the 28 performance indicators is set at a level which gives a good level of assurance that the productivity of all key elements of the ecosystem on which the fishery has an impact are not compromised. The MSC system therefore not only takes into account the impact of the fishery on the target stock, but also other vital components of the wider ecosystem, such as habitat structure, productivity and biodiversity. This minimum level equates to a score of 60 and if the fishery scores below 60 on any one of the 28 Performance Indicators it is an automatic failure. However, achieving only the minimum, 60 performance level is not adequate to become certified against the MSC standard; average scores of at least 80 for the Performance Indicators under each of the three principles have to be achieved. As a result, every fishery certified against the MSC standard is operating at a very high level of precaution. This means the fishery is more resilient to potential changes such as natural stock fluctuations, and better able to secure its long-term sustainability.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/about-us/standards/standards/msc-environmental-standard |title=MSC environmental standard for sustainable fishing — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
Fisheries that want certification and to use the ecolabel pay {{US$|20,000}} to more than $100,000 to an independent, for-profit contractor that assesses the fishery against the MSC standard and determines whether to recommend certification.<ref name=jolly/> The assessors are independently accredited to perform MSC assessments by Accreditation Services International (ASI). After certification, fisheries undergo annual audits costing $75,000 per audit and are recertified every five years.<ref name=jolly>{{cite news|last=Jolly|first=David|title=Certification of Krill Harvest Upsets Conservationists|work=The New York Times|page=6|date=23 June 2010|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/23/science/earth/23krill.html}}</ref>
===Encouraging further improvement in fisheries===
Because a certified fishery must achieve average scores of at least 80 across the three principles it is possible for a fishery to be certified with a score of between 60 and 80 for a small number of performance indicators. In these cases it is called a conditional certification: conditions are placed on the fishery, which it must fulfil within a set period, in order to remain certified. Even though the fishery is operating sustainably, it must introduce a plan of action that will raise its performance to the more precautionary level demanded by the MSC standard by increasing any score of between 60 and 80 to at least 80 within a set period of time. In almost all cases, scores of 80 have to be achieved for all performance indicators by the end of the first certificate period (five years).{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}}
To remain certified, fisheries also have to undertake an annual surveillance to check that they continue to meet the MSC standard. After 5 years, the fishery must be reassessed in full if it wants to continue to be certified.
==Aquaculture== The Marine Stewardship Council is a program for [[Wild fisheries of the world|wild fisheries]] and does not include [[aquaculture]] production.
Some types of ‘enhanced fisheries’ can be certified but there is a well-defined type of enhancement to which the MSC standard for sustainability can be applied:
* The fishery must rely on catching fish from the wild at some stage, either Catch and Grow or Hatch and Catch. * Species must be native to the geographic region of the fishery. * It is not possible to substantially augment the fishes’ food or give them medicines (except in the case of Hatch and Catch fisheries such as salmon hatcheries, where the fry are reared only to a small size prior to release to the wild). * Habitat can be modified but it must be possible to reverse the impact the enhanced fishery has on the habitats and wider ecosystem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/newsroom/news/msc-board-statement-on-aquaculture |title=MSC Board statement on aquaculture — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date=2008-06-16 |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
==Stakeholder input into assessments==
To ensure a robust assessment and to ensure that the independent team of experts has all the available information on the fishery, the assessment process is open to a range of stakeholders to participate – this could be other fisheries, NGOs, governments, or other bodies.
Stakeholders are invited to participate in the process from the outset, and throughout the assessment, stakeholders are given the opportunity to submit information and comment on reports, all of which are made public and available for anyone to see on the MSC website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/track-a-fishery/have-your-say |title=Have your say — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
==Governance==
The MSC is governed by a Board of Trustees of up to 15 members. In addition a Technical Advisory Board and a Stakeholder Council advise the Board. The structure of these bodies involves a wide range of stakeholders with different views so that decisions reflect many sectors and interests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/about-us/governance/structure |title=Structure — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
The Board sets the strategic direction of the MSC, monitors progress and ensures the MSC meets its objectives. The MSC Technical Advisory Board is made up of 15 experts in the fields of marine science, policy and seafood supply chains: it advises the MSC Board on technical and scientific matters. The MSC Stakeholder Advisory Council ensures that the opinions of groups with a stake in sustainable fishing and seafood supply are heard by the MSC Board. It comprises up to 17 members who represent a broad range of sectors and geographical areas, including fishing organisations, NGOs, consumer groups, retailers, and others.
Through these bodies, the MSC is continually improving its program, and stakeholders are invited to contribute to its development through regular meetings of the Stakeholder Advisory Council and public consultations.
==Ensuring seafood purchased is from a sustainable fishery==
The MSC manages a second standard called Chain of Custody for traceability. If seafood is to be sold with the MSC ecolabel, every business in the supply chain must be assessed and certified by an independent body against the MSC Chain of Custody standard. This ensures that only seafood from a certified sustainable fishery is sold with the MSC label.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/about-us/standards/standards/chain-of-custody |title=MSC chain of custody standard for seafood traceability — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
==Finances==
The MSC is a registered charity <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/Showcharity/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=1066806 |title=Charity overview |publisher=Charity-commission.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> and non-profit organisation <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.guidestar.org/organizations/98-0470539/marine-stewardship-council.aspx |title=Nonprofit Report for Marine Stewardship Council |publisher=.guidestar.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> and depends on various sources of funding. From 1 April 2011 to 31 March 2012, the MSC’s total income was £15 million. Total expenditure for the same period was £12 million. The MSC Board recognises it as generally good practice to hold reserves as a protection against any financial difficulties in the future. A reserves target of 6 to 9 months’ cover is considered to be necessary, at least as an aspiration, given the MSC’s absence of a subscribing membership and uncertainty, as a market-based program, of its various income streams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/about-us/finances |title=Our finances — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
==Independent opinion and criticisms== In 2009 Greenpeace published a comprehensive assessment of the MSC. Overall the report states several positive effects, but also many aspects that make the MSC a weak certification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenpeace.org/usa/Global/usa/report/2009/7/assessment-of-the-msc.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-05-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518085600/http://www.greenpeace.org/usa/Global/usa/report/2009/7/assessment-of-the-msc.pdf |archivedate=18 May 2015 |df= }}</ref>
[[Jared Diamond]]'s 2005 book ''[[Collapse (book)|Collapse]]'' discussed MSC and the similar [[Forest Stewardship Council]] as good examples of collaboration among [[environmentalist]]s and businesses for a [[sustainable economy]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Diamond|first=Jared|authorlink=Jared Diamond|title=Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail Or Succeed|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mYPXUHZCp3gC|accessdate=4 December 2011|year=2011|publisher=Penguin Books|location=New York|isbn=0-670-03337-5}}</ref>
Andrew Balmford’s book ''Wild Hope'' (Chicago University Press, 2012) devotes a chapter to the MSC as a successful strategy for achieving conservation goals through a collaborative, market-based solution.
Since 2009, the MSC has been criticized for certifying fisheries that have, in the view of some, questionable sustainability. The most controversial certification has been that of the [[Ross Sea]] [[Antarctic toothfish]] fishery.<ref name=smith2011>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Lewis|title=Sustainable fish customers 'duped' by Marine Stewardship Council|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/jan/06/fish-marine-stewardship-council|accessdate=5 December 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=6 January 2011|location=London}}</ref><ref name="rue89.com">[http://www.rue89.com/planete89/2011/02/22/peche-durable-msc-lecolabel-qui-encourage-le-massacre-191747 Amélie Lescroël and Sylvain Angerand, ''{{lang|fr|Pêche durable : MSC, l'écolabel qui encourage le massacre}}'' / ''Durable fishing: MSC, the ecolabel that promotes the massacre'', ''Rue89 Planète''].</ref> Some scientists and stakeholders in the seafood industry consider the fishery "exploratory", since so little is known about it.<ref name=smith2011/><ref name=jacquet>{{Cite journal | last1 = Jacquet | first1 = J. | last2 = Pauly | first2 = D. | last3 = Ainley | first3 = D. | last4 = Holt | first4 = S. | last5 = Dayton | first5 = P. | last6 = Jackson | first6 = J. | title = Seafood stewardship in crisis | journal = Nature | volume = 467 | issue = 7311 | pages = 28–29 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20811437 | doi = 10.1038/467028a}}</ref> However toothfish has been fished commercially for over 30 years and the fishery has been closely managed by Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources since 1982.<ref>[http://www.ccamlr.org/pu/e/gen-intro.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222175430/http://www.ccamlr.org/pu/e/gen-intro.htm |date=22 February 2012 }}</ref> Scientists had accused the assessor, which recommended the fishery for certification, of ignoring unfavorable data. The independent adjudicator later sent back the recommendation for certification to the assessor for reconsideration.<ref name=jolly/> The fishery was certified with adjustments to the scoring on the contested indicators and additional requirements for providing scientific data to aid research on toothfish stocks.
The MSC received criticism from [[Greenpeace]] and the [[Pew Environment Group]] among others over its certification of [[Antarctic krill]]. Although the fishery may have been healthy, critics believed that "scientific data on the fishery’s impact [wa]s lacking, and that the council’s decision [wa]s thus based on guesswork". As a result, [[Whole Foods Market]] stated it would stop selling all krill oil supplements even with the ecolabel.<ref name=jolly/>
As part of the MSC certification the krill fishery committed to further scientific research and 100% observer coverage, specifically addressing the concerns about risks posed to other species by krill fishing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/track-a-fishery/certified/southern-ocean/aker-biomarine-antarctic-krill/sustainability-notes |title=Sustainability notes — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date=2010-06-14 |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref> Fishing pressure on krill is very low – less than 1% of estimated biomass - and the management rules established by CCAMLR ensure fishing activities minimise risks to the krill population or other species.<ref>[http://www.ccamlr.org/pu/e/sc/kri-surv-intro.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204103907/http://www.ccamlr.org/pu/e/sc/kri-surv-intro.htm |date=4 February 2012 }}</ref>
In early 2010, the MSC was criticised by environmental groups like the [[Sierra Club]] for certifying the [[British Columbia]] [[sockeye salmon]] fishery<ref name=hume>{{cite news|last=Hume|first=Mark|title=Sustainable sockeye ‘eco-fraud'|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/british-columbia/sustainable-sockeye-eco-fraud/article1437794/| newspaper= The Globe and Mail|accessdate=5 December 2011|location=Toronto|date=6 July 2010}}</ref><ref>"[http://www.fis.com/fis/worldnews/worldnews.asp?monthyear=&day=22&id=35267&l=e&special=&ndb=1%20target= MSC criticised for sockeye certification]." ''[[Fish Information and Services]]''</ref><ref>{{cite press release|title=Response to Sockeye Certification by the Marine Stewardship Council |publisher=Sierra Club BC |year=2010 |url=http://www.sierraclub.bc.ca/quick-links/publications/seafood-oceans-1/Response%20to%20MSC%20certification%20of%20sockeye.pdf |accessdate=Dec 5, 2011 |quote= |ref= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920003643/http://www.sierraclub.bc.ca/quick-links/publications/seafood-oceans-1/Response%20to%20MSC%20certification%20of%20sockeye.pdf |archivedate=20 September 2011 }}</ref> when stocks in the [[Fraser River]] (a part of the fishery) had been in decline since the early 1990s.<ref name=casselman>{{cite journal|last=Casselman|first=Anne|title=Upstream Battle: What Is Killing Off the Fraser River's Sockeye Salmon?|journal=Scientific American|date=May 5, 2011|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=what-is-killing-off-fraser-river-sockeye-salmon|accessdate=5 December 2011|issn=0036-8733}}</ref> The year before, the [[salmon run]] of the Fraser River (a part of the fishery) was only 1.4 million (M) of a predicted 11 M salmon and had prompted the [[Canada|Canadian]] Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]] to launch a judicial enquiry.<ref>{{cite news|title=Missing salmon stocks to be probed: PM| url=http://fis.com/fis/worldnews/worldnews.asp?monthyear=11-2009&day=6&id=34470&l=e&country=0&special=&ndb=1&df=0 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091123095358/http://fis.com/fis/worldnews/worldnews.asp?monthyear=11-2009&day=6&id=34470&l=e&country=0&special=&ndb=1&df=0|archivedate=23 November 2009|accessdate=5 December 2011|newspaper=Fish Info & Services|date=6 November 2009|author=AFP|authorlink=Agence France-Presse|agency=Agence France-Presse}}</ref> The 2010 run was 30 M and the 2011 run is estimated to be greater than 4 M.<ref>{{cite news|title=Up to 4 million sockeye expected in run|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2011/08/13/bc-sockeye-gillnetters-opening.html|accessdate=5 December 2011|newspaper=CBC News|date=August 13, 2011|author=Canadian Press|authorlink=The Canadian Press|agency=Canadian Press|location=Toronto}}</ref> The Fraser Sockeye 2010 think tank at [[Simon Fraser University]] stated that the large 2010 run was due mainly to the cyclical peak of fish from the [[Adams River (British Columbia)|Adams River]] and that returns were high only for a subset of [[tributary|tributaries]].<ref name=fs2010>{{cite conference|author=Steering Committee|title=Fraser Sockeye 2010: Findings of a Scientists' Think Tank|url=https://www.sfu.ca/cstudies/science/resources/1291745499.pdf|conference=Fraser Sockeye 2010|conferenceurl=https://www.sfu.ca/cstudies/science/salmon.php|publisher=Speaking for the Salmon Program at Simon Fraser University|accessdate=5 December 2011|date=December 6, 2010}}</ref> However, it stated that "the large unresolved uncertainties […] highlight our collective uncertainty about the relative roles of climate change, aquaculture, and fisheries management in determining salmon returns".<ref name=fs2010/>
An appropriate management response to the decreased stocks was taken and the fishery was closed to allow the stocks to recover. The fishery is now operating successfully and has an ongoing commitment to protecting weak populations and decreasing bycatch. Catch level is set in-season in accordance with each year's run size.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/track-a-fishery/certified/pacific/british-columbia-sockeye-salmon/fishers-story |title=British Columbia sockeye salmon: the fishers' story — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date= |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
In February 2011, several European [[World Wildlife Fund|WWF]] chapters objected to certification of the Denmark [[North Sea]] [[plaice]] fishery.<ref name=holland>{{cite web|last=Holland|first=Richard|title=Objection: Denmark North Sea Plaice Trawl Fishery|url=http://www.msc.org/track-a-fishery/certified/north-east-atlantic/Denmark-North-Sea-plaice/Objection-documents-1/17.02.2011-Objection%20Denmark%20trawl%20plaice.pdf|work=Memo to MSC|publisher=Marine Stewardship Council|accessdate=5 December 2011|date=11 February 2011}}</ref> The concerns raised were taken into account and the fishery concerned implemented a habitat strategy to ensure enhanced protection of vulnerable habitats through measures such as closed areas, gear modifications, technical developments and targeted research.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msc.org/newsroom/news/danish-north-sea-plaice-trawl-fishery-receives-msc-certificate?fromsearch=1&newsquery=denmark+north+sea+plaice&year=&month=&isnewssearch=1 |title=Danish North Sea plaice trawl fishery receives MSC certificate — MSC |publisher=Msc.org |date=2011-06-10 |accessdate=2013-04-06}}</ref>
However, in an independent study of seven different seafood ecolabelling and certification programs, commissioned by WWF International and carried out by Accenture Development Partnerships in 2009,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://wwf.panda.org/wwf_news/?206131/Marine-Stewardship-Council-MSC-Wild-Seafood-Sustainability-Certification-Remains-Best-In-Class|title=Marine Stewardship Council wild seafood sustainability certification remains best in class|access-date=2018-08-09|language=en}}</ref> the MSC ranked highest across all 103 criteria. The study was repeated in 2012 and the MSC again was determined ‘best in class’, scoring twice as highly as the next nearest certification program analysed.
Some scientists like [[Sidney Holt]] and [[Daniel Pauly]] have suggested that a system where assessments are carried out by commercial contractors paid by the fisheries creates a [[conflict of interest]] because assessors have a financial incentive in recommending fisheries and getting more work and profits from the resulting annual audits.<ref name=jacquet/> However, the practice of companies paying external auditors for assessments to independent standards (such as accounting or quality standards) is widespread throughout all business and non-profit sectors. Third party assessment by accredited certifiers, independent of the standard setter, is also a key feature of the United Nations FAO guidelines on ecolabelling fisheries and fish products, and one of the criteria that the global community of MSC stakeholders value in the MSC program.<ref name=jolly/>
In December 2016 ''[[Private Eye]]'' reported that a leaked internal WWF document concluded that because the MSC receives royalties from licensing its ecolabel (providing 75% of the organisation's revenue) there is a [[conflict of interest]] and it has relaxed its sustainability requirements, enabling more products to carry its label, thereby increasing its own income.<ref>{{cite magazine |last= |first= |date=9 December 2016 |title=Singing out of tuna |magazine=[[Private Eye]] |location=London |publisher=Pressdram Ltd }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Aquaculture Stewardship Council]] *[[Forest Stewardship Council]]

Ato Tesfaye Basha, V/P-IT |num_employees =Over 3,000 |revenue = |industry = [[Bank]] |products = [[Financial services]] |homepage = {{URL|www.orointbank.com}} }} '''Oromia International Bank''' (OIB) is a private bank based in [[Addis Ababa]], [[Ethiopia]]. It was established on September 18, 2008.{{cite web|title=Oromia International Bank S.C|url=http://www.orointbank.com/}} ==Overview== Oromia International Bank S.C began operation on October 25, 2008 with a starting capital of 110 million [[Ethiopian birr|birr]] (Br), surpassing the minimum capital requirement by 35 million Br. With its headquarters located inside Dembel City Centre, on Africa Avenue (Bole Road). Established with the commercial banking business objectives, OIB is undertaking a universal commercial banking services such as deposit mobilization, lending of money, remittance service, and international banking services and interest free banking. The Bank has now launched Electronic banking outputs such as Card banking known as Oro-Card(ATM and POS), Mobile Banking named as Oro-Cash, Agent Banking-Oro Agent and Internet banking namely Oro-Click. The number of OIB branches are now reached 225 throughout Ethiopia all connected by core banking system. Oromia Int'l Bank owns a 13 storey building Headquarters in Addis Ababa City on Bole road next to Getu Commercial Center. The Bank is now one of the most influential and popular private banks in Ethiopia and also known for pioneering Interest free banking services. ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.orointbank.com Official Website] [[Category:Banks of Ethiopia]] [[Category:Banks established in 2008]] [[Category:Oromia Region]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Ethiopia]] {{Ethiopia-stub}} {{Africa-bank-stub}}

'''''Sen Son Kon Rak''''' ({{lang-th|เส้นสนกลรัก}}; {{RTGS|''Sen Son Kon Rak''}}) was a Thai romantic-drama TV series that aired on [[Channel 3 (Thailand)|Channel 3]], it starred [[Pongsakorn Mettarikanon]], [[Kamolned Ruengsri]] and [[Pitchapa Phanthumchinda]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.siamzone.com/drama/1507/|title=My Hero วีรบุรุษสุดที่รัก ตอน เส้นสนกลรัก|last=|first=|date=|website=SIAMZONE.COM|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> It's the forth drama of project "''My hero''".
== Plot == Khong Thamdee ([[Pongsakorn Mettarikanon]]) who came from broken family became social worker whose purpose in life is to help others. One of latest case is Miao ([[Kamolned Ruengsri]]), a broken one.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ch3thailand.com/%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%8A%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%873/second/493/My-hero-%E0%B8%A7%E0%B8%B5%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%A9%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%94%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B5%E0%B9%88%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%81---%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%AA%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%81.html|title=My hero วีรบุรุษสุดที่รัก : เส้นสนกลรัก|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ch3thailand.com|language=th-TH|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
== Cast ==
=== Main cast ===
* [[Pongsakorn Mettarikanon]] as Khong Thamdee * [[Kamolned Ruengsri]] as Montha Phasuk (Miao) * [[Pitchapa Phanthumchinda]] as Thicha
=== Supporting cast ===
* [[Saranyoo Prachakrit]] as Peera * [[Sawitree Samipak]] as Rawi * [[Pornnapra Theptinnakorn]] as Thapthim * [[Pharunyoo Rojanawuttitham]] as Chai * [[Natha Lloyd]] as Nari Op-ari * [[Jaidee Deedeedee]] as Surarak Tathip * [[Sumet Ong-at]] as Kamchai Trongsucharit * [[Somjit Jongjohor]] as Sawai * [[Kosawis Piyasakulkaew]] as Pae Panyakraikul * [[Kluay Chernyim]] as Sawat * [[Noi Phongam]] as Jaeo * [[Korakot Thanaphat]] as Phrom * [[Rungnapha Benjamaporn]] as Wan * [[Chonlamak Tha Chiangthong]] as Rai * [[Saranthon Khlai-udom|Saranthon Klaiudom]] as Ple * [[Suppanad Jittaleela]] as Nang * [[Ronnawee Sereerat]] as Saen * [[Natnischa Cerdchoobuphrakaree]] as Noina * [[Nisawan Silpapearsue]] as Jiaranai Denwai * [[Narongsak Angkap]] as Dam * [[Kanthida Chang]] as Som
=== Guests ===
* [[Sinjai Plengpanich]] as Teacher Chanthra * [[Pakorn Chatborirak]] as Major Techat Wasutraphaisan (Ben) * [[Warintorn Panhakarn]] as Teacher Patsakorn Wirayakan (Pat) * [[Jaron Sorat]] as Itsara Ratchaphonkun * [[Louis Scott (actor)|Louis Scott]] as Akhin Nopprasit * [[Duanghathai Sathathip]] as Nid

== External links ==

{{Infobox UN | name = UN Publications UNCTAD review of Maritime Transport | image = | image size = | caption = | type = | acronyms = | headquarters = | {{ISBN|978-92-1-112860-4}} | e-{{ISBN|978-92-1-055950-8}} | status = | established = 1968 | website = [http://www.unctad.org www.unctad.org] | parent = | commons = United Nations | footnotes = }} The '''UNCTAD Review of Maritime Transport''' (RMT) an annual publication that has been published since 1968 by the [[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development]] (UNCTAD). It provides an analysis of structural and cyclical changes affecting seaborne trade, ports and shipping, as well as an extensive collection of statistical information <ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/publications/Review-of-Maritime-Transport-%28Series%29.aspx</ref>
The RMT is prepared by the Division on Technology and Logistics of the [[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development|UNCTAD]] secretariat, it is an important source of information on the port sector. It closely monitors developments affecting world seaborne trade, freight rates, ports, surface transport and logistics services, as well as trends in ship ownership, [[Port State Control|port]]/[[flag state]] control, fleet age, tonnage supply and productivity.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.porteconomics.eu/news/noticeboard/item/269-unctad-review-of-maritime-transport-2011.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502102736/http://www.porteconomics.eu/news/noticeboard/item/269-unctad-review-of-maritime-transport-2011.html |archivedate=2014-05-02 |df= }}</ref>
==Structure of publication== The review of maritime transport provides insights on:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/publications/Review-of-Maritime-Transport-%28Series%29.aspx</ref>
*Seaborne trade *Emerging trends affecting maritime transport *Fleet ownership and registration *Shipbuilding and demolitions *Freight rates *Liner shipping connectivity *Port traffic *Legal and regulatory developments *A topical issue covered in a special chapter
==RMT List of yearly Special chapter== *1997:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1583</ref> Review of regional developments in small island developing countries *1998:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1592</ref> Trade and transport of East and South-East Asia *1999:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1601</ref> Recent trade and transport developments in Latin America *2000:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1609</ref> Developments in the sub-Saharan African economic area and maritime transport *2001:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1618</ref> Regional developments in trade and transport networks in East Asia, China and Japan *2002:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1628</ref> Container port traffic and container terminal throughput *2003:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1637</ref> Developments in African trade and maritime transport *2004:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1647</ref> Developments in Asian trade and maritime transport. *2005:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1656</ref> Developments in Latin American and Caribbean trade and maritime transport *2006:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1666</ref> Sub Saharan Africa *2007:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1676</ref> Asia *2008:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1686</ref> Latin America and Caribbean *2009:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1696</ref> Africa *2010:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1708</ref> Asia *2011:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationArchive.aspx?publicationid=1734</ref> Developing countries in different maritime businesses. *2012:<ref>http://unctad.org/en/pages/PublicationWebflyer.aspx?publicationid=380</ref> Sustainable freight transport development and finance
==See also== [[Ship Transport]]
[[Merchant vessel]]
[[UNCTAD]]
==External links== * [http://www.porteconomics.eu Porteconomics] is a web-based initiative of the [[European Union]], aiming at generating knowledge about seaports. It is developed and empowered by the members of the PortEconomics group, that are actively involved in academic and contract research in port economics, management, and policy. * [http://unctad.org UNCTAD] intergovernmental body that publishes the RMT
==References== {{reflist|2}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = d2h | logo = d2h1image.jpg | logo_size = 250px | type = Subsidiary of [[Dish TV]] | foundation = June 2009{{cite web | url=http://www.videocond2h.com/wsc/about.aspx | title=About Us | publisher=d2h | accessdate=19 July 2016 }} | location = [[Mumbai]], India | caption = "Asia's Most Promising DTH Brand" | | area_served = India | industry = Satellite television | products = [[Pay television]]
[[pay-per-view]]
[[satellite television]]
[[Direct-broadcast satellite television|DTH]]
[[direct-broadcast satellite]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = [[Essel Group]] | subsid = | traded_as = | homepage = {{URL|www.d2h.com}} }} '''d2h ''' is an Indian [[Pay television|pay TV]] brand, part of Dish TV India Ltd providing [[Satellite television|direct broadcast satellite]] service—including satellite television, audio programming, and interactive television services to commercial and residential customers in India. As of December 31, 2017, d2h has a market share of 19% among the pay DTH operators.{{Cite news|url=http://trai.gov.in/release-publication/reports/performance-indicators-reports|title=Performance Indicators Reports|work=Telecom Regulatory Authority of India|access-date=2018-05-25|language=en}} [[Dish TV]] India and d2h merger has been concluded, which has created the largest DTH service provider in the country with a subscriber base of about 29 million.{{cite web|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/media/entertainment/media/dish-tv-india-videocon-d2h-merger-completed/articleshow/63414778.cms |title=Dish TV India, Videocon d2h merger completed |publisher=economictimes.indiatimes.com |date=22 March 2018 |accessdate=22 March 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/dish-tv-plans-to-continue-with-videocon-d2h-brand/articleshow/64022878.cms|title=Dish TV plans to continue with Videocon D2H brand - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-05-25}} ==Technical information== d2h has 10,54 MHz transponders on Satellite ST-2. d2h is aligned at 88° East on the Clarke Belt. d2h uses [[MPEG-4]] technology, which permits high compression for video and DVB-S2 technology, which allows more efficient transmission of satellite signals. It uses H.264 or [[MPEG-4]] Part 10, Advanced Video Coding (MPEG-4 AVC) with DVB S2 digital compression technology, transmitting using [[ST-2]] satellite. == Merger== On 11 November 2016, the Board of Directors of Videocon d2h and [[Dish TV]] agreed to an all-stock merger of their DTH operations. The merger has created the largest DTH provider in India with a total valuation of {{INRConvert|17000|c}}. The merged entity will be called Dish TV Videocon Limited.{{Cite news|url=https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/uFvAQCYWZwaNKuyMmB2EGM/Videocon-DishTV-merger-set-to-enjoy-benefits-of-scale.html|title=Videocon-DishTV merger set to enjoy benefits of scale|last=Bansal|first=Shuchi|date=2018-03-29|work=www.livemint.com|access-date=2018-05-25}} Dish TV will hold a 55.4% stake in the merged entity, while Videocon d2h will own the remaining shares.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/dish-tv-videocon-d2h-become-one-entity/article23323731.ece|title=Dish TV, Videocon d2h become one entity|work=@businessline|access-date=2018-05-25|language=en}} The merger was approved by the [[Competition Commission of India]] (CCI) on 10 May 2017,{{cite web|last1=Ahluwalia|first1=Harveen|title=Dish TV and Videocon d2h merger gets CCI approval|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/FULbZN0PRVxgPcBVeI0nEN/Dish-TV-and-Videocond2h-merger-gets-CCI-approval.html|website=www.livemint.com/|accessdate=18 November 2017|date=10 May 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/media/entertainment/media/cci-approves-dish-tv-videocon-merger/articleshow/58610594.cms|title=CCI approves Dish TV-Videocon merger|date=2017-05-10|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-05-25}} and by the National Company Law Tribunal on 27 July 2017.{{cite web|last1=India|first1=Press Trust of|title=NCLT approves Dish TV-Videocon D2h merger, to have subscriber base of 27 mn|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/nclt-approves-dish-tv-videocon-d2h-merger-to-have-subscriber-base-of-27-mn-117072701774_1.html|website=Business Standard India|accessdate=18 November 2017|date=27 July 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/govt-approves-dish-tv-merger-with-videocond2h/article21823209.ece|title=Govt. approves Dish TV merger with Videocond2h|date=2017-12-16|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-12-29|others=Special Correspondent|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} The merger faced uncertainty in January 2018, when Dish TV announced that it was re-evaluating the merger after some of the Videocon Group's lenders petitioned the National Company Law Tribunal to open insolvency proceedings against the company.{{cite web|url=https://www.livemint.com/Companies/A4THURMxplzY6ymJuqbPJK/Videocon-Dish-TV-merger-may-get-affected-by-insolvency-case.html|title=Videocon-Dish TV merger may get affected by insolvency case against Videocon Industries|last1=Dhanjal|first1=Swaraj Singh|date=12 January 2018|website=www.livemint.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 April 2018}} In February 2018, Dish TV announced that it intended to go through with the merger.{{cite web|title=Zee’s Dish TV to go ahead with Videocon D2H merger|url=https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/zees-dish-tv-to-go-ahead-with-videocon-d2h-merger/article22681521.ece|website=Hindu Business Line|accessdate=11 April 2018|language=en}} The amalgamation was officially completed on 22 March 2018. The merger made the new combined entity the largest DTH provider in India with around 29 million active subscribers. Dish TV and Videocon d2h reported separate revenue numbers in FY2017. The combined total revenue of the two firms was {{INRConvert|8077|c}}.{{cite web|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/media/entertainment/media/dish-tv-india-videocon-d2h-merger-completed/articleshow/63414778.cms|title=Dish TV India, Videocon d2h merger completed|date=22 March 2018|website=The Economic Times|accessdate=11 April 2018}} And After some time. [[Videocon Group|Videocon]] Pvt. Ltd. Was bankrupt.￼ == References == {{reflist|refs=http://www.televisionpost.com/dth/no-subscriber-additions-for-reliance-digital-tv-in-q4/}} == External links == * [http://www.videocond2h.com Official website] {{DTH in India}} {{CATV_Africa,_Asia,_and Oceania}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Videocon d2h}} [[Category:Videocon]] [[Category:High-definition television]] [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Indian television networks]] [[Category:Indian brands]] [[Category:Companies based in Mumbai]] [[Category:Companies established in 2009]] [[Category:Companies listed on NASDAQ]]
